examples_1: Choosing to purchase cheap, budget plane tickets, the traveler swapped comfort for financial savings.

meaning: a person or thing that protects somebody or something from being harmed by another
examples_0: The wine glasses came with a cardboard around them to buffer any shock from shipping.
examples_1: A buffer of security personnel protected the celebrity as they walked the red carpet.

meaning: food laid out in this way, to which diners serve themselves
examples_0: We enforce a policy that diners may return to the buffet up to three times to refill their plates.
examples_1: Mark told me about a bar that serves up drinks buffet style so that they don?t have to pay for a bartender.

meaning: afflicted/harmed over and over for a long period of time
examples_0: The football team was buffeted over the season, being beaten by every single team they played.
examples_1: Dropping stock markets were being buffeted by forces that seemed to want a total market failure.

meaning: a silly person who tries to be humorous but comes across as foolish
examples_0: Since you are making a buffoon of yourself, you should go sit quietly in a corner before you embarrass me further!
examples_1: I wonder when my thirty-year-old son will stop acting like a buffoon and begin to take life seriously.

meaning: silly behavior or habits
examples_0: Jim got suspended because he failed to realize school was not the place to display a clown?s buffoonery.
examples_1: Working together, the two comics were able to turn their buffoonery into a half-hour comedy show.

meaning: a small brass instrument that resembles a trumpet and is usually sounded before an announcement
examples_0: Each call from the brass bugle had a different meaning for the recruits who knew the signals well.
examples_1: Similar to the trumpet, the keyed bugle is a brass instrument but is smaller in size.

meaning: having the shape of or resembling a bulb; bloated
examples_0: The round, bulbous plants seemed to bloom on every corner of the street.
examples_1: Bulging out of his head, the irate customer?s bulbous eyes frightened the clerk.

meaning: a rounded bump or swelling that juts outward on a surface
examples_0: The bulge of the man?s muscle showed through his fitted t-shirt.
examples_1: Maternity clothes were needed since her current duds barely covered the bulge of her belly.

meaning: the larger part of something
examples_0: The bulk of the leftover food will go to the food pantry, but some will have to be thrown away.
examples_1: Because a bulk of her money would be used to pay her bills, Karen knew she would have to watch her spending this month.

meaning: large and heavily built or shaped
examples_0: The bulky package was much too large to be placed in the small mailbox.
examples_1: Big and bulky, the bride?s dress barely fit inside the luxurious limousine.

meaning: a newsletter or memo that generally announces important information
examples_0: The community news bulletin listed garage sales, events, and other important information for the neighborhood.
examples_1: The charity organization mailed out their monthly bulletin and listed where all of the funds raised were spent.

meaning: an object that acts as a shield
examples_0: Vaccines act as a bulwark against many childhood diseases.
examples_1: When the ruler travelled around his territory, his guards accompanied him as a bulwark from enemy attack.

meaning: acting or moving about in a confused manner
examples_0: The drunk man was bumbling around the bar, knocking over tables and bumping into other patrons every few seconds.
examples_1: Some people find it funny to watch animals on painkillers bumbling around the house, since they can barely control their movements.

meaning: to confuse someone
examples_0: In an attempt to bumfuzzle his mother, Tony hid her keys in the microwave and pretended to know nothing about it.
examples_1: The twists and turns in the corn maze were confusing enough to bumfuzzle any of the fall party guests.

meaning: something that is disappointing
examples_0: Not getting the job was a bit of a bummer, but I?m hopeful that I will snag one soon.
examples_1: The hurricane hitting during our vacation was a big bummer that caused us to have to cancel the whole trip.

meaning: confident in an annoying manner
examples_0: While Rick is very intelligent, he would be more likable if he were not so bumptious about his educational background.
examples_1: My coworker is so bumptious and overbearing that people try and avoid her at lunch.

meaning: a group of objects held together by wrapping or tying
examples_0: Newspapers are delivered to stores in a bundle.

meaning: a group of something tied or joined together
examples_0: Before they could start a fire, the campers had to pile up a bundle of sticks in the middle of the rocks.
examples_1: The newspaper boy still had a whole bundle of papers to pass out before lunchtime.

meaning: a small, one-story house with a front porch and a low-pitched roof
examples_0: The couple slept in a small bungalow that was built on top of the clear Caribbean Sea.
examples_1: Mr. Hatchets? thatched roof bungalow was barely big enough for he and his wife.

meaning: to clumsily perform a task
examples_0: Because the police department is comprised of idiots, it will probably bungle the simple case.
examples_1: My boss will fire me if I bungle this project.

meaning: something that is foolish, ridiculous, and makes no sense
examples_0: The doomsday extremist spouted bunkum about how the world would end in seven days when the ozone layer spontaneously combusted.
examples_1: Many people think that global warming is complete bunkum, but scientists have numerous statistics to back up their assertion.

meaning: a float in water that is used to mark something
examples_0: To alert boaters of the hazard ahead, a small buoy was used to mark the sandbar near the surface.
examples_1: You can be a human buoy, floating in the water by wearing your life jacket.

meaning: joyful and self-assured
examples_0: With a great deal of confidence, the buoyant model strolled down the runway.
examples_1: When I talked to my doctor, he was buoyant about my weight loss under the new diet.

meaning: a heavy load
examples_0: Finding he had cancer, he tried to shoulder the burden alone and keep the news from his friends.
examples_1: Lying can be a heavy burden to carry, often making it difficult to keep stories straight.

meaning: a problem or inconvenience
examples_0: Babysitting for my neighbors had become a burden when they wanted me to work over 40 hours a week while going to school.
examples_1: My mother didn?t want to be a burden on her children during her old age, so she decided to live in a nursing home.

meaning: tough to fulfill or carry out
examples_0: After accepting several jobs, Lily realized it was burdensome for her to try to juggle all of those jobs.
examples_1: Once Carol?s co-worker quit, the job was a burdensome chore for Carol to keep up with it.

meaning: an agency or governmental department
examples_0: Although it is their job, officials at the labor bureau refuse to support worker rights.
examples_1: After a federal investigation, the bureau agreed to become more transparent with agency spending.

meaning: a method of business or government in which red tape processes are used to delay action
examples_0: The bureaucracy of the legislative government is delaying the passage of much needed educational funding.
examples_1: In the waiting room, we were given numerous documents to complete as part of the hospital's pretreatment bureaucracy.

meaning: associated with a lengthy and tiresome process for performing a task
examples_0: Because of bureaucratic red tape, it will be months before I receive my passport.
examples_1: Bureaucratic mistakes allowed a wrongly imprisoned man to stay in jail for over three months.

meaning: to grow and expand rapidly
examples_0: As car prices go down, car dealers are expecting sales to burgeon.
examples_1: Because Janice is pregnant with triplets, everyone is expecting her stomach to burgeon quickly.

meaning: a robber or thief that enters a building illegally to steal
examples_0: The burglar isn?t known for stealing jewels or money, but hijacking hamburgers and french fries.
examples_1: One burglar broke in through a window while a second thief entered through the back door.

meaning: illegal entry into a building or vehicle with the intention of stealing
examples_0: Because he had been convicted of burglary before, Nick was the prime suspect in this hotel break-in.
examples_1: Another burglary string has taken hold of the area, with vehicles being broken into all over the city.

meaning: the act or ceremonial practice of placing something (usually a dead body) underground
examples_0: Before the burial ceremony, grave diggers dug out a space for the coffin.
examples_1: Helen?s daughters dressed her up in her finest gown and prepared the hearse for her burial.

meaning: coarse, plain-woven fabric used for bagging, furniture, and rugs
examples_0: Burlap bags are being woven to hold potatoes and produce to be sold at the market.
examples_1: Oyster collectors fill hundreds of heavy burlap sacks on a good day and a handful on a difficult one.

meaning: a stage production or literary piece that uses excessive exaggeration or comedic imitation to ridicule something or someone
examples_0: The burlesque war film depicts our president as a kid playing with toy soldiers.
examples_1: In the burlesque essay, the animals portray exaggerated versions of some of society?s elite.

meaning: large, strong and heavy
examples_0: When he attempted an escape, a burly police officer had to forcefully restrain the suspect.
examples_1: The lumberjack?s burly frame took up the entire doorway.

meaning: to polish; to make smooth or shiny
examples_0: Richard is forever attempting to burnish his reputation so that he can advance his position within our company.
examples_1: I applied car polish to my Porsche repeatedly, making sure to burnish it to perfection.

meaning: seared; scorched
examples_0: My siblings think it is disgusting that I prefer my meat burnt and overcooked on the grill.
examples_1: In the Native American version of Cinderella, the girl?s fair skin was burnt by her evil sister who used fire cinders to scorch her.

meaning: to dig in order to make a hole or tunnel
examples_0: The rabbit tried to burrow himself down in the ground so that the fox wouldn?t catch him.
examples_1: Some animals, like the mole, like to burrow down underground to make their nest.

meaning: to explode suddenly
examples_0: Rocks falling down during the landslide burst apart, breaking into a million pieces.
examples_1: My stomach is so full, it feels as if it is about to burst.

meaning: to cover completely, typically with dirt or some other earthy substance as an act of hiding or putting to rest
examples_0: Dogs like to bury their bones and toys in the yard.
examples_1: All of their family and friends headed to the cemetery to bury her father.

meaning: a measure of capacity equal to 8 gallons, used for dry goods
examples_0: The bushel of oats would yield enough for many bowls of cereal.
examples_1: Once the small gardener harvested his grains, he produced a bushel of wheat.

meaning: hurriedly, in a very active way
examples_0: The servants hurried through the kitchen, busily preparing for the king?s feast.
examples_1: Two and full of energy, Amber moves busily around the playroom.

meaning: the activity of buying and selling goods and services, especially as one?s living
examples_0: When the real estate market crashed, the business of selling homes came to a creeping halt.
examples_1: Because business is booming, Jerry can invest more money back into his product line.

meaning: a sculpture or statue of a person?s head, shoulders, or chest
examples_0: The artist created the bust to show how beautiful the woman?s face was.
examples_1: A bust showing Caesar from the shoulders up will be displayed in the statue section of the museum.

meaning: something used to break something else apart
examples_0: The laundry spray is a grease buster that can break up even the toughest stains.
examples_1: A master at getting horses to do what he wants, the buster was able to break the will of any stallion.

meaning: to move in a noisy or hurried manner
examples_0: On Valentine?s Day men bustle about the store trying to find last minute gifts.
examples_1: Jane was running late so she had to bustle to reach her office on time.

meaning: a person who is always in other people?s business, meddling and starting trouble
examples_0: The busybody next door is always snooping on the neighbors and trying to figure out what they are doing.
examples_1: An old busybody, Mirna, goes around the office telling other people?s business and gossiping with others.

examples_0: For over two centuries, the U.S. Constitution has been a buttress for the government.
examples_1: Claudio?s professor told him he needed to do some more research to find data to be a buttress for his theory.

meaning: describing a full-figured female with an ample bosom
examples_0: Because Gail is a buxom woman, she has to custom order her bras.
examples_1: The men applaud loudly when the buxom stripper removes her blouse.

meaning: obtain in exchange for payment
examples_0: She went to the mall to buy a new dress for her interview.
examples_1: The single mother winced every time she went to the store to buy groceries.

meaning: a low hiss with a ?z? sound
examples_0: At first I didn?t hear the buzz from the bees until I got closer to the bee hive around the corner.
examples_1: When there was a buzz coming from the car?s engine, the car?s owner described to the mechanic that his car had a snake sound coming from the engine.

meaning: a hawk-like bird of prey that soars high with wide wings and a round tail
examples_0: The buzzard circled around the dead deer carcass and zoomed in to snatch some of the meat with his talons.
examples_1: Like other birds of prey, the plundering buzzard enjoys preying on small animals.

meaning: a person or thing that stops others from enjoying themselves
examples_0: Taylor?s constant talk about religion and other depressing subjects made him a total office buzzkill.
examples_1: Jason really liked Emma at first, but her low-self esteem and nagging ended up being a buzzkill when they went out.

meaning: a secondary product or result that's produced in the making or doing of something else
examples_0: Dorothy was told that a by-product of her pregnancy was nausea and vomiting, but that it would subside after her first trimester.
examples_1: My dad views democracy as a by-product of freedom and that it cannot thrive without meeting certain conditions.

meaning: associated with an earlier period of time
examples_0: These days getting married before having a baby appears to be the concept of a bygone era.
examples_1: When Jane put on her vintage dress, she looked like a woman from the bygone 1940s.

meaning: to go around something
examples_0: While driving home, I decided to bypass the construction work and take a different route.
examples_1: If you are on a diet, you should bypass the bread and have a salad instead.

meaning: a person who is present during a situation or event but not directly involved
examples_0: A bystander witnessed the wreck and called the police to assist.
examples_1: Without a bystander to confirm his story, it was the man?s word against the officers.

meaning: complex; hard to comprehend
examples_0: Because the plot was revealed in a byzantine manner, it was difficult to understand.
examples_1: I was totally confused after listening to the byzantine recording.
